active_time_window.description: The Active Time Window defines your expected product usage frequency. Users who are active across multiple time windows are considered retained.

day.description: Product used multiple times a day as a part of daily habits. Provides instant benefits or fulfils immediate needs.
day.examples: Email, Zoom, LinkedIn, WhatsApp, News, Fitbit, Monzo

week.description: Product used once or a few times per week, often planned like weekly meetings or entertainment. Provides value on a regular, but not daily basis.
week.examples: Hubspot, Canva, Trello, Asana, Deliveroo, Hello Fresh, Calliper

month.description: Product used once a month, often connected to long-term tracking, planning, or budgeting. Value is provided in relation to monthly events or responsibilities.

active_time_window.update_error: Failed to update active time window

excluded_users.description: Select which users you want to exclude from your product analytics data, usually test or demo accounts.

define_power_user.description: Power users often integrate your product into their core business workflow or habit. In the early stages, it helps picking one user signal to define your power user. Power users are defined within your active time window.
define_power_user.update_error: Failed to update power user event

info_signals.description: A signal is any event in your product that is tied to a core feature being used and a user receiving value from your product.

info_errors.description: You shouldnâ€™t be making a funnel here, these events should be distinct and separate. Ideally these signals should also be tied to how users are charged or where there is potential for users to upgrade if they hit a usage limit.

pipelines.notice: Selecting multiple pipelines will combine all the deal data from each pipeline.
